(Welcome to/Unleash/Explore) a more beautiful web{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}} | developer = [[Microsoft]] | released = {{Start date and age|2011|03|14}} | operating system = [[Windows 7]]
[[Windows Vista]] [[Windows Vista#Service Pack 2|Service Pack 2]]
[[Windows Server 2008]] [[Windows Vista#Service Pack 2|Service Pack 2]]
[[Windows Server 2008 R2]]
[[Windows Phone 7.5]]{{cite web | url = http://www.zdnet.co.uk/news/mobile-it/2011/02/15/windows-phone-7-update-to-offer-ie9-40091800/ | title = Windows Phone 7 update to offer IE9 | author = Stephen Shankland | publisher = [[cNET.com|CNET News]] | date = February 15, 2011 | accessdate = 2011-03-24 }} | engine = [[Trident (layout engine)|Trident 5.0]]
[[Chakra (JScript engine)|Chakra]] ([[JScript]]) | language = 93 languages{{cite news |url = http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ie/archive/2011/05/25/internet-explorer-9-now-available-in-93-languages.aspx |title = Internet Explorer 9 Now Available in 93 Languages |work = IEBlog: The Windows Internet Explorer Weblog |agency = [[MSDN Blogs]] |publisher = Microsoft Corporation |date = 25 May 2011 |accessdate = 26 May 2011 |first1 = Vishwac Sena |last1 = Kannan |first2 = Kevin |last2 = Luu }} | genre = [[Web browser]]

{{URL|www.beautyoftheweb.com/}} | Footer = [[Internet Explorer]] versions:
{{Msieversions}} }} '''Windows Internet Explorer 9''' (abbreviated as '''IE9''') is the current version of the [[Internet Explorer]] [[web browser]] from [[Microsoft]]. It was released to the public on March 14, 2011 at 21:00 PDT.{{cite web |url = http://windowsteamblog.com/ie/b/ie/archive/2011/03/09/a-more-beautiful-web-launches-on-march-14th.aspx |title = A More Beautiful Web Launches on March 14th |publisher = The Windows Blog}} Internet Explorer 9 supports several [[CSS 3]] properties, embedded [[International Color Consortium|ICC]] v2 or v4 [[ICC profile|color profiles]] support via [[Windows Color System]], and has improved [[JavaScript]] performance. It is the last of the five major [[web browser]]s to implement support for [[SVG|Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG)]].http://www.w3.org/Graphics/SVG/IG/wiki/SVG_Plugin_for_IE It also features [[Hardware acceleration|hardware-accelerated]] graphics rendering using [[Direct2D]], hardware-accelerated text rendering using [[DirectWrite]], hardware-accelerated video rendering using [[Media Foundation]], imaging support provided by [[Windows Imaging Component]], and high fidelity printing powered by the [[Open XML Paper Specification|XML Paper Specification (XPS)]] print pipeline.{{cite web |url = http://blogs.msdn.com/ie/archive/2010/04/09/Benefits-of-GPU-powered-HTML5.aspx |title = Benefits of GPU-powered HTML5 |work = IEBlog |publisher = Microsoft corporation |date = 9 April 2010 |accessdate = 26 February 2011 }} Internet Explorer 9 also supports the [[HTML5 video]] and audio tags and the [[Web Open Font Format]].{{cite web |url=http://blogs.msdn.com/ie/archive/2010/04/23/meet-woff-the-standard-web-font-format.aspx |title=Meet WOFF, The Standard Web Font Format |work = IEBlog |publisher=Microsoft Corporation |date=23 April 2010 |first=Sylvain |last=Galineau}} Microsoft has released Internet Explorer 9 as a major out-of-band version that is not tied to the release schedule of any particular version of Windows, unlike previous versions.{{cite web |url = http://www.winsupersite.com/live/ie9_preview.asp |title = Internet Explorer 9 Preview |work = Paul Thurrott's Supersite for Windows |publisher = Penton Media, Inc. |last = Thurrott |first = Paul |date = 18 November 2009 |accessdate = 26 February 2011 }} The system requirements for Internet Explorer 9 are [[Windows 7]], [[Windows Server 2008 R2]], [[Windows Vista]] Service Pack 2 or [[Windows Server 2008]] SP2 with the [[Windows Vista Platform Update|Platform Update]].{{cite web|url=http://support.microsoft.com/kb/2117917 |title=Platform Update Supplement for Windows Vista and for Windows Server 2008 |publisher=Support.microsoft.com |date=2011-02-08 |accessdate=2011-05-10}} [[Windows XP]] and earlier are not supported. Internet Explorer 9 is the last version of Internet Explorer to be supported on Windows Vista; [[Internet Explorer 10]] will only be supported on Windows 7 and later.{{cite web | url=http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2383640,00.asp | title=Internet Explorer 10 drops Vista support | work=[[PC Magazine]] | publisher=Ziff Davis, Inc | date=2011-04-15 | accessdate=2011-04-21 | last=Muchmore | first = Michael }}{{cite web | url=http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9215791/Windows_Vista_No_IE10_for_you | title=Windows Vista: No IE10 for you | work=[[Computerworld]] | publisher=Computerworld Inc | date=2011-04-13 | accessdate=2011-04-21 | last = Keizer | first = Gregg }}{{cite web |url=http://windows.microsoft.com/en-US/internet-explorer/downloads/ie-9/worldwide-languages |title = Download languages for Internet Explorer 9 |work = [[microsoft.com]] |publisher=Microsoft Corporation |accessdate=26 February 2011 }}{{cite web |url=http://dvice.com/archives/2010/03/internet-explor.php |title=Internet Explorer 9 adds HTML5, drops Windows XP |work = [[Dvice.com]] |publisher = [[NBC Universal]] |first=Kevin |last=Hall |date=17 March 2010 }}{{cite web |url=http://blogs.zdnet.com/microsoft/?p=5572&tag=col1;post-5572 |title=Microsoft IE9 developer preview with HTML5 support ready for download |work = [[ZDNet]] |publisher = CBS Interactive |first = Mary Jo |last = Foley |date = 16 March 2010 |accessdate = 26 February 2011 }} Both [[IA-32|32-bit]] and [[x86-64|64-bit]] builds are available. ==Release history== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Name ! Build ! Release Date ! [[Acid3]] Score ! New notable features |- | style="white-space:nowrap; background:lightgrey;"| Internet Explorer 9 Platform Preview 1 | 1.9.7745.6019 | style="width:90px" | 2010-03-16{{citation |url=http://blogs.msdn.com/ie/archive/2010/03/16/html5-hardware-accelerated-first-ie9-platform-preview-available-for-developers.aspx |title=HTML5, Hardware Accelerated: First IE9 Platform Preview Available for Developers |publisher=Microsoft |first=Dean |last=Hachamovitch |date=2010-03-16}} | 55/100{{citation |url=http://ie.microsoft.com/testdrive/benchmarks/Acid3-pp1/Default.html |title=The Web Standards Project's Acid3 Test â Platform Preview 1 |publisher=Microsoft}} | Support for [[CSS3]] and [[SVG]] and a new [[JavaScript]] engine called [[Chakra (JavaScript engine)|Chakra]]. |- | style="white-space:nowrap; background:lightgrey;"| Internet Explorer 9 Platform Preview 2 | 1.9.7766.6000 | style="width:90px" | 2010-05-05{{citation |url=http://blogs.msdn.com/ie/archive/2010/05/05/html5-and-same-markup-second-ie9-platform-preview-available-for-developers.aspx |title=HTML5 and Same Markup: Second IE9 Platform Preview Available for Developers |publisher=Microsoft |first=Dean |last=Hachamovitch |date=2010-05-05}} | 68/100{{citation |url=http://ie.microsoft.com/testdrive/benchmarks/Acid3-pp2/Default.html |title=The Web Standards Project's Acid3 Test â Platform Preview 2 |publisher=Microsoft}} | Better JavaScript performance. |- | style="white-space:nowrap; background:lightgrey;"| Internet Explorer 9 Platform Preview 3 | 1.9.7874.6000 | style="width:90px" | 2010-06-23{{citation |url=http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ie/archive/2010/06/23/html5-native-third-ie9-platform-preview-available-for-developers.aspx |title=HTML5, Native: Third IE9 Platform Preview Available for Developers |publisher=Microsoft |first=Dean |last=Hachamovitch |date=2010-06-23}} | 83/100{{citation |url=http://ie.microsoft.com/testdrive/benchmarks/Acid3-pp3/Default.html |title=The Web Standards Project's Acid3 Test â Platform Preview 3 |publisher=Microsoft}} | [[Comparison of layout engines (HTML5 Media)|HTML5 audio]], [[HTML5 video|video]], and [[Canvas element|canvas]] tags, and [[Web Open Font Format|WOFF]]. |- | style="white-space:nowrap; background:lightgrey;"| Internet Explorer 9 Platform Preview 4 | 1.9.7916.6000 | style="width:90px" | 2010-08-04{{citation |url=http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ie/archive/2010/08/04/html5-modernized-fourth-ie9-platform-preview-available-for-developers.aspx |title=HTML5, Modernized: Fourth IE9 Platform Preview Available for Developers |date=2010-08-04 |first=Dean |last=Hachamovitch |authorlink=Dean Hachamovitch |publisher=Microsoft}} | rowspan="8" | 100/100{{citation |url=http://ie.microsoft.com/testdrive/benchmarks/Acid3/Default.html |title=The Web Standards Project's Acid3 Test â Platform Preview 4 |publisher=Microsoft}} |JavaScript engine integrated into the core browser components.{{cite web|url=http://arstechnica.com/microsoft/news/2010/08/microsoft-releases-final-internet-explorer-9-platform-preview.ars|title=Inside the final Internet Explorer 9 Platform Preview|publisher=[[arstechnica]]}} |- | style="white-space:nowrap; background:lightgrey;"| Internet Explorer 9 Platform Preview 5 | 1.9.7930.16406 | rowspan="2" style="width:90px" | 2010-09-15{{citation |url=http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9180659/Microsoft_to_release_IE9_public_beta_on_Sept._15 |title=Microsoft to release IE9 public beta on Sept. 15 |date=2010-08-13 |first=Gregg |last=Keizer |publisher=[[Computerworld]]}} | New icon. |- | style="white-space:nowrap; background:lightgrey;"| Internet Explorer 9 Beta | 9.0.7930.16406 | New user interface. |- | style="white-space:nowrap; background:lightgrey;"| Internet Explorer 9 Platform Preview 6 | 1.9.8006.6000 | style="width:90px" | 2010-10-28{{citation |url=http://www.downloadsquad.com/2010/10/28/ie9-beta-downloaded-10-million-times-more-details-on-developer/ |title=IE9 Beta downloaded 10 million times, more details on Developer Preview 6 |date=2010-10-28 |first=Sebastian |last=Anthony |publisher=Download Squad}} | CSS3 2D transforms and HTML5 semantic tags.{{cite web |url = http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ie/archive/2010/10/28/html5-using-the-whole-pc-sixth-ie9-platform-preview-available-for-developers.aspx |title = HTML5, Using the whole PC: Sixth IE9 Platform Preview Available for Developers |publisher = Microsoft |last = Hachamovitch |first = Dean |authorlink = Dean Hachamovitch |date = 2010-10-28 |accessdate = 2010-10-28}} |- | style="white-space:nowrap; background:lightgrey;"| Internet Explorer 9 Platform Preview 7 | 1.9.8023.6000 | style="width:90px" | 2010-11-17{{cite web |url = http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ie/archive/2010/11/17/html5-and-real-world-site-performance-seventh-ie9-platform-preview-available-for-developers.aspx |title = HTML5, and Real World Site Performance: Seventh IE9 Platform Preview Available for Developers |publisher = Microsoft |last = Hachamovitch |first = Dean |authorlink = Dean Hachamovitch |date = 2010-11-17 |accessdate = 2010-11-17}} | Better JavaScript performance. |- | style="red-space:nowrap; background:lightgrey;"| Internet Explorer 9 Platform Preview 8 | 1.9.8080.16413 | rowspan="2" style="width:90px" | 2011-02-10{{cite web |url = http://www.neowin.net/news/internet-explorer-9-rc-to-launch-on-february-10 |title = Internet Explorer 9 RC to launch on February 10 |publisher = Neowin.net |last = Brad |first = Sams |date = 2011-02-10|accessdate = 2011-02-04}} | Performance, interoperability enhancements, and support for the [[W3C Geolocation API]]. |- | style="red-space:nowrap; background:lightgrey;"| Internet Explorer 9 Release Candidate | 9.0.8080.16413 | Improved performance, ''InPrivate Filtering'' renamed to ''Tracking Protection'', a refined UI, support for more web standards, the option to add a new tab row, and other improvements. |- | style="green-space:nowrap; background:#a0e75a;"| Internet Explorer 9 | 9.0.8112.16421 | style="width:90px" | 2011-03-14 | Improved performance, improved Tracking Protection, and the option to pin multiple targets per page. |} ==Development== [[File:Acid3 3.png|thumb|right|Internet Explorer 9 displaying [[Acid3]]]] Development of Internet Explorer 9 began shortly after [[Internet Explorer 8]] was released. Microsoft began taking features suggestions through Microsoft Connect soon after Internet Explorer 8 was released.{{citation |url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/Forget-about-IE8-Onward-to-Internet-Explorer-9-in-Windows-7-74575.shtml |title=Forget about IE8 - Onward to Internet Explorer 9 in Windows 7 |last=Oiaga |first=Marius |date=2007-12-20 |publisher=[[Softpedia]] |accessdate=2010-03-19}} The Internet Explorer team focused on improving support for [[HTML5]], [[CSS3]], [[SVG]], [[XHTML]], and the user interface featuring agility and "a clean new design".{{Cite news|url=http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ie/archive/2010/09/15/ie9-beta-available-for-download.aspx|title=Introducing Internet Explorer 9 Beta â Internet Explorer Blog at MSDN|work=Microsoft Developer Network|publisher=Microsoft|date=15 September 2010|accessdate=30 November 2010}} Microsoft first announced Internet Explorer 9 at [[Professional Developers Conference|PDC 2009]] and spoke mainly about how it takes advantage of hardware acceleration in [[DirectX]] to improve the performance of [[web applications]] and improve the quality of [[web typography]]. Later, Microsoft announced that they had joined the W3C's [[SVG Working Group]], which sparked speculation that Internet Explorer 9 will support the SVG [[W3C recommendation]].{{cite web|url=http://blogs.msdn.com/ie/archive/2009/11/18/an-early-look-at-ie9-for-developers.aspx|title=An Early Look At IE9 for Developers|date=2009-11-18|first=Dean|last=Hachamovitch|work=IEBlog on [[Microsoft Developer Network]]|publisher=[[Microsoft]]|accessdate=2009-11-18}} This was proven to be true at [[MIX (Microsoft)#MIX 10|MIX 10]], where they demonstrated support for basic SVG markup and improved support for HTML5. They also announced that they would increase the support greatly by the time the first Internet Explorer 9 Beta was released. The Internet Explorer team also introduced the new JavaScript engine for 32-bit Internet Explorer 9, codenamed Chakra, which uses [[Just-in-time compilation]] to execute JavaScript as native code.{{cite web | url = http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2009/05/29/q-a-64-bit-internet-explorer.aspx | title = Q&A: 64-Bit Internet Explorer | author = Eric Law | date = May 29, 2009 | publisher = Microsoft | work = MSDN Blogs > EricLaw's IEInternals | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5xLWkEWWv | archivedate = 2011-02-21 }}{{citation |url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/Internet-Explorer-9-Beta-Next-New-IE9-Builds-Every-8-Weeks-138013.shtml |title=Internet Explorer 9 Beta Next â New IE9 Builds Every 8 Weeks |last=Oiaga |first=Marius |date=2010-03-20 |publisher=[[Softpedia]] |accessdate=2010-03-31}}{{citation |url=http://blogs.msdn.com/ie/archive/2010/01/05/microsoft-joins-w3c-svg-working-group.aspx |title=Microsoft Joins W3C SVG Working Group |date=2010-01-05 |first=Patrick |last=Dengler |work=IEBlog on [[Microsoft Developer Network]] |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |accessdate=2009-01-05}} In mid-September 2011, the Acid3 test was revised to remove a few "antiquated and unusual" tests and as a result IE9 now passes the test with a score of 100/100{{citation |url=http://www.tomsguide.com/us/acid3-browser-test-web-standard-compatibility-IE9,news-12583.html | title=Acid3 Test Simplified |publisher=Tom's Hardware}} At MIX 10, the first Internet Explorer 9 Platform Preview was released, which featured support for CSS3 and SVG, a new [[JavaScript]] engine called [[Chakra (JavaScript engine)|Chakra]], and a score of 55/100 on the [[Acid3]] test, up from 20/100 for [[Internet Explorer 8]]. On May 5, 2010, the second Internet Explorer 9 Platform Preview was released, which featured a score of 68/100 on the [[Acid3]] test and faster performance on the [[SunSpider|WebKit SunSpider JavaScript benchmark]] than the first Internet Explorer 9 Platform Preview. On June 23, 2010, the third Internet Explorer 9 Platform Preview was released, which featured a score of 83/100 on the Acid3 test and a faster JavaScript engine than the second Internet Explorer 9 Platform Preview. The third Internet Explorer 9 Platform Preview also includes support for HTML5 audio, video, and canvas tags, and [[WOFF]]. On August 4, 2010, the fourth Internet Explorer 9 Platform Preview was released, which features a score of 95/100 on the Acid3 test and a faster JavaScript engine than the third Internet Explorer 9 Platform Preview. On September 15, 2010, the Internet Explorer 9 Public Beta was released alongside Platform Preview 5, featuring a new user interface. In contrast to the previews, the Beta replaces any previously installed version of Internet Explorer. The sixth Internet Explorer 9 Platform Preview was released on October 28, 2010, and includes support for CSS3 2D transforms and HTML5 semantic elements. The seventh Internet Explorer 9 Platform Preview was released on November 17, 2010, and features better JavaScript performance.http://ie.microsoft.com/testdrive/benchmarks/SunSpider/Table.html These previews were not full builds of Internet Explorer 9, as they were for testing the latest version of the [[Trident (layout engine)|Trident]] layout engine. They were for web developers to send feedback on the improvements made, functioned in parallel with any other installed browsers, and were previews of the renderer technology only, containing minimalistic user interfaces and lacking traditional interface elements such as an address bar and navigation buttons.{{citation |url=http://ie.microsoft.com/testdrive/info/FrequentlyAskedQuestions/Default.html |title=Frequently Asked Questions |date=2010-03-13 |accessdate=2010-03-18 |publisher=[[Microsoft]]}} Microsoft updated these previews approximately every eight weeks. On November 23, 2010, two updates for the Internet Explorer 9 Public Beta were released. KB2448827 brings improvements to reliability and fixes stability issues from the previous beta release. There are not much details of resolved issues disclosed by Microsoft. Moreover, KB2452648 resolves the in-built feedback issue with Internet Explorer 9 and the latest version of Windows Live Sign-in Assistant.{{Cite news|url=http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ie/archive/2010/11/23/updates-for-internet-explorer-9-beta.aspx|title=Updates for Internet Explorer 9 Beta - Internet Explorer Blog at MSDN|work=Microsoft Developer Network|publisher=Microsoft|date=23 November 2010|accessdate=23 November 2010}} These updates can be fetched from [[Windows Update]] or the Microsoft Download Center website.{{Cite news|url=http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/en/details.aspx?FamilyID=00c694cf-e182-4383-ad0f-3f24e94097ee|title=Update for Windows Internet Explorer 9 Beta for Windows Vista and Windows Server 2008 (KB2448827)|publisher=Microsoft|accessdate=23 November 2010|date=23 November 2010}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/en/details.aspx?FamilyID=c5b94711-620c-42b7-8f9f-e2e08ee4c433&utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=twitter&utm_campaign=Feed:+MicrosoftDownloadCenter+(Microsoft+Download+Center)|title=Update for Internet Explorer 9 Beta feedback Tool for Windows Vista 64-bit Edition and Windows Server 2008 64-bit Edition (KB2452648)|publisher=Microsoft|date=23 November 2010|accessdate=23 November 2010}} On the same day, Internet Explorer build 9.0.8027.6000 based on Internet Explorer 9 Platform Preview 7 was leaked.{{cite web|url=http://www.ditii.com/2010/11/23/internet-explorer-9-beta-2-build-9-0-8027-6000-leaked-to-the-web/ |title=Internet Explorer 9 Beta 2 Build 9.0.8027.6000 Leaked to the Web |publisher=Ditii.com |date=2010-11-23 |accessdate=2011-05-10}} On February 10, 2011, the Internet Explorer 9 [[Release Candidate]] and Platform Preview 8 were released. The Release Candidate version featured improved performance, a Tracking Protection feature, a refined UI, support for more web standards, and other improvements.{{cite web | url=http://www.engadget.com/2011/02/10/internet-explorer-9-rc-now-available-to-download-tracking-prote/ | title=Internet Explorer 9 RC now available to download, tracking protection in tow (update) | accessdate=12 February 2011 | date=10 February 2011 | publisher=Engadget}} The final version of Internet Explorer 9 was publicly released on March 14, 2011 during the [[South by Southwest]] (SXSW) music and film festival in Austin, Texas. ==Changes from previous versions== ===User Interface=== Internet Explorer 9 includes significant alterations to its user interface when compared with previous versions. These include: * Pinned Sites:{{cite web |url = http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/gg131029(VS.85).aspx |title = Pinned Sites: Windows 7 Desktop Integration with Internet Explorer 9 |work = [[Microsoft Developer Network]] |publisher = Microsoft |date = 15 September 2010 |accessdate = 26 February 2011 |first = I. |last = Hilerio }}[http://www.beautyoftheweb.com/#/startdeveloping/pinning Pinning], Beauty of the Web. Integrates with the Windows 7 taskbar to make web site experience more like an application where users may "pin" a site and then return to it later like a shortcut. In the release candidate, users can pin a site and add more homepages to that site (e.g. pin [[Facebook]] and add [[Twitter]] as another homepage to that pinned site, so it would become a social program) * Security-enabled Download Manager: Manages file transfers and can pause and resume downloads and informs if a file may be malicious * Enhanced Tabs and Tab Page: the new tab page can show most visited sites, and tabs are shown next to the address bar (there is an option to have a separate row, like in [[Internet Explorer 8]]) with the feature of closing an inactive tab. * Add-on Performance Advisor: Shows which third-party add-ons may be slowing down browser performance and then allows the option to disable or remove them * Compact user interface.[http://windows.microsoft.com/en-US/internet-explorer/help/ie-9/whats-new-in-internet-explorer-9 Whatâs new in Internet Explorer 9?] windows.microsoft.com ===Scripting=== ====JavaScript engine==== {{Main|Chakra (JavaScript engine)}} {{See also|Comparison of layout engines (ECMAScript)}} Internet Explorer 9 (32-bit) features a faster JavaScript engine than Internet Explorer 8's, internally known as [[Chakra (JavaScript engine)|Chakra]]. Chakra has a separate background thread for compiling JavaScript. Windows runs that thread in parallel on a separate core when one is available. Compiling in the background enables users to keep interacting with webpages while Internet Explorer 9 generates even faster code. By running separately in the background, this process can take advantage of modern multi-core machines.{{citation |url=http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ie/archive/2010/03/16/html5-hardware-accelerated-first-ie9-platform-preview-available-for-developers.aspx |title=HTML5, Hardware Accelerated: First IE9 Platform Preview Available for Developers |first=Dean |last=Hachamovitch |authorlink=Dean Hachamovitch |date=2010-03-16}} In Microsoft's preliminary SunSpider benchmarks for the third 32-bit Internet Explorer 9 Platform Preview, it outperformed the Internet Explorer 8 engine by a factor of 10 and also outperformed the newest Firefox 4.0 pre-release.{{citation |url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/IE9-Races-for-Fastest-Browsers-in-the-World-Spot-with-Chrome-Firefox-Opera-and-Safari-145545.shtml|title=IE9 Races for Fastest Browsers in the World Spot with Chrome, Firefox, Opera and Safari |date=2010-06-26 |publisher=Softpedia.com}} Microsoft provided information that its new javascript engine uses [[dead code elimination]] optimization for faster performance, which included a small section of code in the SunSpider test as dead code.{{citation|url=http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ie/archive/2010/11/17/html5-and-real-world-site-performance-seventh-ie9-platform-preview-available-for-developers.aspx|title=HTML5, and Real World Site Performance: Seventh IE9 Platform Preview Available for Developers|date=2010-11-17}} Robert Sayre, a Mozilla developer investigated this further, showing that Internet Explorer 9's preview 3 dead code elimination had bugs, providing test cases exposing these bugs resulting in wrong compilation.{{cite web |url=http://blog.mozilla.com/rob-sayre/2010/11/17/dead-code-elimination-for-beginners/ |title=Dead Code Elimination for Beginners |first=Rob |Sayre |date=2010-11-17 |accessdate=2010-11-18}} After its final release, 32-bit Internet Explorer 9 has been tested to be the leading mainstream browser in the Sunspider performance test.{{cite web| title=Internet Explorer 9 speeds past the competition | url=http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9214674/Internet_Explorer_9_speeds_past_the_competition?taxonomyId=167&pageNumber=2| author=Preston Gralla| date=2011-03-16|publisher=Computerworld}} The engine significantly improves support for ECMA-262: [[ECMAScript]] Language Specification standard, including features new to the recently finalized Fifth Edition of ECMA-262 (often abbreviated ES5).{{citation |url=http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ie/archive/2010/07/16/how-ie9-platform-preview-feedback-changed-the-javascript-standard.aspx |title=How IE9 Platform Preview Feedback Changed the JavaScript Standard |first=Allen |last=Wirfs-Brock |date=2010-07-16 |publisher=Microsoft}} The Internet Explorer 9 browser release scored only 3 faults{{or|date=April 2011}} from 10440 tests in the [http://test262.ecmascript.org/default.html Test262 Ecmascript conformace test] (Ver. 0.6.2 5-Apr-2011) created by [[Ecma International]]. The 64-bit version of Internet Explorer 9, which is not the default browser even on 64-bit systems, does not have the JIT compiler{{cite web | url = http://www.zdnet.com/blog/networking/chrome-10-vs-internet-explorer-9-reconsidered/792?pg=2 | title = Chrome 10 vs. Internet Explorer 9 Reconsidered | publisher = [[ZDNet]] | date = March 10, 2011 | author = Steven J. Vaughan-Nichols | accessdate = 2011-03-21 }} and performs up to 4 times slower. ====DOM==== {{See also|Comparison of layout engines (Document Object Model)}} [[Document Object Model|DOM]] improvements include: * DOM Traversal and Range * Full DOM L2 and L3 events * getComputedStyle from DOM Style * DOMContentLoaded ===CSS=== {{See also|Comparison of layout engines (Cascading Style Sheets)}} Internet Explorer 9 has improved [[Cascading Style Sheets]] (CSS) support. The Internet Explorer 9 implementation report, which was created using Internet Explorer 9 Beta, shows Internet Explorer 9 passing 97.7% of all tests on the [[W3C]] CSS 2.1 test suite.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ie/archive/2010/10/08/css-2-1-implementation-reports.aspx| title=CSS 2.1 Implementation Reports| author=Adrian Bateman|date=2010-10-08}} This is the highest pass rate amongst CSS 2.1 implementation reports submitted to W3C.{{cite web|url=http://test.csswg.org/harness/results?s=CSS21&t=0|title=CSS 2.1 Test Suite Results|publisher=W3C}} CSS3 improvements include support for the following modules: * CSS3 2D Transforms {{cite web|url=http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/ie/ff468705#_CSS3_2D_Transforms| title=Internet Explorer 9 Guide for Developers - CSS3 2D Transforms (CSS3)|publisher=Microsoft|date=2011-03-14}} * CSS3 Backgrounds and Borders {{cite web|url=http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/ie/ff468705#_CSS3_BG_Borders| title=Internet Explorer 9 Guide for Developers - CSS3 Backgrounds & Borders Module (CSS3)|publisher=Microsoft|date=2011-03-14}} * CSS3 Color {{cite web|url=http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/ie/ff468705#_CSS3_Colors| title=Internet Explorer 9 Guide for Developers - CSS3 Color Module (CSS3)|publisher=Microsoft|date=2011-03-14}} * CSS3 Fonts {{cite web|url=http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/ie/ff468705#_CSS_Fonts| title=Internet Explorer 9 Guide for Developers - CSS3 Fonts Module |publisher=Microsoft|date=2011-03-14}} * CSS3 Media Queries {{cite web|url=http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/ie/ff468705#_CSS3_Media_Queries| title=Internet Explorer 9 Guide for Developers - CSS3 Media Queries Modulele (CSS3)|publisher=Microsoft|date=2011-03-14}} * CSS3 Namespaces {{cite web|url=http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/ie/ff468705#_CSS3_Namespaces| title=Internet Explorer 9 Guide for Developers - CSS3 Namespaces Module |publisher=Microsoft|date=2011-03-14}} * CSS3 Values and Units {{cite web|url=http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/ie/ff468705#_CSS3_Values_Units| title=Internet Explorer 9 Guide for Developers - CSS3 Values and Units Module (CSS3)|publisher=Microsoft|date=2011-03-14}} * CSS3 Selectors {{cite web|url=http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/ie/ff468705#_CSS3_Selectors| title=Internet Explorer 9 Guide for Developers - CSS3 Selectors |publisher=Microsoft|date=2011-03-14}} ===HTML5=== ====HTML5 Media==== {{See also|Comparison of layout engines (HTML5 Media)}} Internet Explorer 9 includes support for the HTML5 video and audio tags. The audio tag will include native support for the [[MP3]] and [[Advanced Audio Coding|AAC]] codecs, while the [[HTML5 video|video tag]] will natively support [[H.264/MPEG-4 AVC]].{{citation |url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/IE9-Platform-Preview-3-HTML5-Evolution-Canvas-Video-and-Audio-Elements-Now-Supported-145416.shtml |title=IE9 Platform Preview 3 HTML5 Evolution: Canvas, Video and Audio Elements Now Supported |first=Marius |last=Oiaga |publisher=[[Softpedia]]}} Support for other video formats, such as [[WebM]], will require third-party plugins. ====HTML5 Canvas==== {{See also|Comparison of layout engines (HTML5 Canvas)}} Internet Explorer 9 includes support for the [[Canvas element|HTML5 canvas tag]].{{citation |url=http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ie/archive/2010/07/01/ie9-includes-hardware-accelerated-canvas.aspx |title=IE9 Includes Hardware Accelerated Canvas |first1=Paul |last1=Cutsinger |first2=Jatinder |last2=Mann |date=2010-07-01 |publisher=Microsoft}} ====HTML5 Inline SVG support==== {{See also|Comparison of layout engines (Scalable Vector Graphics)}} The first Internet Explorer 9 Platform Preview has support for:{{cite web|url=http://blogs.msdn.com/ie/archive/2010/03/18/svg-in-ie9-roadmap.aspx|title=SVG in IE9 Roadmap|publisher=IEblog|date=2010-03-18}} * Methods of embedding: inline HTML, inline XHTML,
